Immune complexes were absorbed to protein G-Sepharose, washed four times, and analyzed by Western blotting. 48 h after transfection, cells were harvested in phosphate-buffered saline and divided in half. One aliquot was lysed in lysis buffer (Promega), and β-galactosidase assays were performed (21Tora L. White J.H. Brou C. Tasset D. Webster N. Scheer E. Chambon P. Cell. 1989; 59: 477-487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (890) Google Scholar) to assess transfection efficiency. The other aliquot was lysed directly in SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis sample buffer and used for Western analysis. Blots were incubated with a combination of anti-GAL4 DBD monoclonal antibodies 2GV3 and 3GV2 (19White J.H. Brou C. Wu J. Lutz Y. Moncollin V. Chambon P. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 2229-2240Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar) diluted 1/1000 in Tris-buffered saline-Tween and 1% milk powder. Western analysis of hsp90 was performed using anti-hsp90 monoclonal antibody SPA-835 (Stressgen). Blots were developed using the ECL detection system (DuPont NEN). Gradients were performed as described by Chambraud et al. (5Chambraud B. Berry M. Redeuilh G. Chambon P. Baulieu E.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20686-20691Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Extracts were made in the presence of phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride and protease inhibitors and stabilized with 30 mM sodium molybdate. Fractions (150 μl) were collected from the top of the gradient and assayed by scintillation counting. We were interested in constructing functional ER derivatives that would not interact with hsp90 in vitro to analyze the potential role of heat shock proteins in controlling ER activity. Region D of the receptor has been shown to participate in ER-hsp90 interactions in vitro (5Chambraud B. Berry M. Redeuilh G. Chambon P. Baulieu E.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20686-20691Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Since mutation of region D would disrupt stable DNA binding (15Mader S. Chambon P. White J.H. Nucleic Acids Res. 1993; 21: 1125-1132Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar), the ER DBD was replaced with that of GAL4 by fusing the GAL4 DBD to the C-terminal portion of the ER from aa 251 to 300 (Fig. 1A). Any hormone-free GAL-ER chimeras, which do not interact with hsp90, would be expected to be nuclear and possibly DNA-bound. Thus, it would be useful to use transactivation as an assay for nuclear localization and DNA binding. However, wild-type ER bound to DNA in the absence of ligand would be hormone-dependent for transactivation, since the transactivating domain AF-1 (Fig. 1A) has been shown to synergize strongly with ligand-bound AF-2 (21Tora L. White J.H. Brou C. Tasset D. Webster N. Scheer E. Chambon P. Cell. 1989; 59: 477-487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (890) Google Scholar). Therefore, the N-terminal A/B region containing AF-1 was replaced with the strong hormone-independent activating domain of the herpes simplex virus activator VP16 (Fig. 1A), which does not synergize with AF-2 (21Tora L. White J.H. Brou C. Tasset D. Webster N. Scheer E. Chambon P. Cell. 1989; 59: 477-487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (890) Google Scholar). In addition, we used a synthetic promoter containing five GAL4 17-mer binding sites (17M5-TATA-luc, Fig. 1A), since VP16 functions highly synergistically when bound to multiple sites. VP16-GAL, which lacks the ER ligand binding domain (LBD), is a strong constitutive activator of 17M5-TATA-luc (Fig. 1B, V-G). This activity is 200-fold higher than that from a promoter containing a single 17-mer binding site (data not shown) and 50-fold higher than the hormone-dependent activity of GAL-ER (Fig. 1B, G-ER), demonstrating the powerful transcriptional activity of VP16. Transactivation by VP16-GAL-ER chimeras on 17M5-TATA-luc in the absence of hormone was 15-35% of that observed with VP16-GAL. Estradiol consistently stimulated transactivation by chimeras 4-fold (with the exception of VP16-GAL-ER281; 3-fold), to levels similar to those observed with VP16-GAL. While this induction is less than the 6-9-fold stimulation observed with the wild-type ER (data not shown), it is striking given that VP16 is a strong constitutive activator. Several Western analyses showed that all recombinants were expressed at similar levels (Fig. 1C and data not shown) and that expression levels were not dependent on the presence of estradiol (Fig. 1B, inset), thus indicating that the reduced level of transactivation by VP16-GAL-ER chimeras in the absence of hormone relative to VP16-GAL was not due to low levels of expression. Glycerol gradients were used to analyze molybdate-stabilized extracts of cells transfected with the wild-type-ER or VP16-GAL-ER chimeras for interaction with hsp90. The wild-type ER displayed a characteristic salt-dependent shift in sedimentation coefficient (5Chambraud B. Berry M. Redeuilh G. Chambon P. Baulieu E.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20686-20691Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) from the 8 S hsp90-containing complex, to the hsp90-free 4 S form (Fig. 2A). In contrast, 4 S, but no 8 S complex formation, was observed in extracts of cells transfected with VP16-GAL-ER258 (Fig. 2B) or VP16-GAL-ER300 (not shown), indicating that they did not interact with hsp90. Western analysis of gradient fractions showed that peak hormone binding corresponds to peaks of intact protein, suggesting that no significant proteolysis of chimeras occurred (Fig. 2B). No interaction of VP16-GAL-ER258 with hsp90 was detected by immunoprecipitation with anti-GAL antibodies of molybdate-stabilized whole cell extracts of transiently transfected COS-7 cells or of the 4 S peak from a glycerol gradient (Fig. 2C, lanes 1-6). Identical results were obtained using anti-ER antibody F3 (not shown). In contrast, immunoprecipitation of HEG0 expressed in COS-7 cells with F3 led to increased coimmunoprecipitation of hsp90 (Fig. 2C, lanes 7-9). These results suggest that interaction with hsp90 does not control hormone-dependent transactivation by the chimeras. Gel retardation assays were also performed to test for hormone-dependent DNA binding. No significant effect of hormone on DNA binding by VP16-GAL-ER258 or VP16-GAL-ER300 was detected in assays performed with extracts made in the presence or absence of estradiol (Fig. 1D and data not shown). In this respect, the chimeras functioned similarly to the wild-type ER (22Metzger D. Berry M. Ali S. Chambon P. Mol. Endocrinol. 1995; 9: 579-591Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). 2H. S. Lee, J. Aumais, and J. H. White, unpublished results. Hormone dependence of VP16-GAL-ER chimeras may be due to interaction with factors, other than hsp90, which repress transcription in the absence of hormone. A series of deletion mutants were created to test which portions of the ER LBD are responsible for the reduced transactivation in the absence of estradiol (Fig. 3A). C-terminal truncations beyond ER aa 553, which disrupt the integrity of the LBD, generated chimeras displaying low levels of constitutive transactivation (Fig. 3B). Significant constitutive activity is recovered, however, with C-terminal deletions beyond aa 430 to aa 370 and further to aa 302. Disruption of the LBD N terminus by deletion past aa 302 to aa 340, 370, or 430 generated chimeras exhibiting low levels of constitutive activity (Fig. 3B). Significant constitutive activation was only recovered by deletion of the N terminus to aa 470. Taken together, these data indicate that a portion of the LBD, primarily sequences between aa 370 and 470, is required for repressed transcription observed in the absence of hormone. Our results suggest that the mechanism of action of the ER is intermediate between that of the GR subfamily of steroid receptors and those of the thyroid hormone/retinoid/vitamin D3 nuclear receptors. The apo-GR is cytoplasmic, and ligand binding leads to its translocation to the nucleus where it binds palindromic DNA sequences as a homodimer (23Pratt W.B. Bioessays. 1992; 14: 841-848Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). The cytoplasmic location of the aporeceptor would be consistent with its interaction in vitro with hsp90, which is predominantly cytoplasmic. In contrast, the thyroid hormone and related receptors do not interact with hsp90 in vitro (24Dalman F.C. Sturzenbecker L. Levin A.A. Lucas D.A. Perdew G.H. Petkovich P.M. Chambon P. Grippo J.F. Pratt W.B. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 5605-5608Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), are nuclear in the absence of hormone and bind to response elements composed of directly repeated motifs as heterodimers with retinoid X receptors (25Yu V.C. Delsert C. Andersen B. Holloway J. Devary O.V. Naar A. Kim S.Y. Boutin J.-M. Glass C.K. Rosenfeld M.G. Cell. 1991; 67: 1251-1266Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1062) Google Scholar, 26Leid M. Kastner P. Lyons R. Nakshatri H. Saunders M. Zacharewski T. Chen J.-Y. Staub A. Garnier J.-M. Mader S. Chambon P. Cell. 1992; 68: 377-395Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1022) Google Scholar). The ER, like the GR, recognizes palindromic response elements as a homodimer (1Green S. Chambon P. Trends Genet. 1988; 4: 309-314Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (831) Google Scholar, 2Evans R.M. Science. 1988; 240: 889-895Crossref PubMed Scopus (6341) Google Scholar, 3Wahli W. Martinez M. FASEB J. 1991; 5: 2243-2249Crossref PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar, 4Gronemeyer H. Annu. Rev. Genet. 1991; 25: 89-123Crossref PubMed Scopus (327) Google Scholar). Numerous studies have indicated that the full-length ER interacts with hsp90 in vitro, suggesting that similar interactions may occur in vivo. Immunoprecipitation experiments by others have also indicated that the isolated ER LBD interacts weakly with hsp90 (18Scherrer L.C. Picard D. Massa E. Harmon J.M. Simons S.S. Yamamoto K.R. Pratt W.B. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 5381-5386Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). However, the LBD used contains a Gly400→ Val mutation, which destabilizes its structure (22Metzger D. Berry M. Ali S. Chambon P. Mol. Endocrinol. 1995; 9: 579-591Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 27Tora L. Mullick A. Metzger D. Ponglikitmongkol M. Park I. Chambon P. EMBO J. 1989; 8: 1981-1986Crossref PubMed Scopus (372) Google Scholar). Our glycerol gradient analyses with VP16-GAL-ER chimeras containing a Val400 mutation have shown that, unlike their Gly400 counterparts, these chimeras form salt-sensitive 8 S complexes in vitro (not shown). In vivo studies, including immunocytochemistry and gene transfer experiments, have provided evidence for the presence of homodimers of apo-ER in the nucleus (13Zhuang Y. Katzenellenbogen B.S. Shapiro D.S. Mol. Endocrinol. 1995; 9: 457-466Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 14Tzukerman M. Zhang X.-K. Herman T. Wills K.N. Graupner G. Pfahl M. New Biol. 1990; 2: 613-620PubMed Google Scholar), which would be inconsistent with stable interaction with hsp90. Taken together, the above results suggest that if the ER interacts with hsp90 in vivo, this interaction is transient, and that a significant concentration of homodimeric aporeceptor is present in the nucleus. Our results show that ER derivatives, which do not interact with hsp90 in vitro, can function as ligand-dependent transactivators in vivo. This occurs in spite of the fact that the VP16-GAL-ER chimeras contain an acidic activating domain which is strongly constitutively active when not tethered to the ER LBD. These results suggest that interaction with hsp90 in vivo is not essential for controlling ligand-dependent transactivation by the ER. It appears that the chimeras tested here are maintained in a transcriptionally repressed state in the absence of ligand, given that ligand induces transactivation to levels similar to those seen with the constitutive activator VP16-GAL. There are several potential candidates for a repressor. In yeast, HSP70 acts downstream of hsp90 to control ER and GR function (28Bohen S.P. Kralli A. Yamamoto K.R. Science. 1995; 268: 1303-1304Crossref PubMed Scopus (183) Google Scholar). It is possible that molecules analogous to those that repress the thyroid hormone and retinoic acid receptors (29Hörlein A.J. Näär A.M. Heinzel T. Torchia J. Gloss B. Kurokawa R. Ryan A. Kamei Y. Söderstrom M. Glass C.K. Rosenfeld M.G. Nature. 1995; 377: 397-404Crossref PubMed Scopus (1714) Google Scholar, 30Chen J.D. Evans R.M. Nature. 1995; 377: 454-457Crossref PubMed Scopus (1715) Google Scholar) also act on the ER. A repressor may be specific or have a broad spectrum of effects on transcription similar to the yeast factor SSN6 (31McDonnell D.P. Vegeto E. O'Malley B.W. Proc. Nat. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10563-10567Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). Deletion analyses of the ER suggest that a putative repressor would interact with a region of the LBD between aa 370 and 470 (Fig. 3). The obvious function of a putative repressor would be to maintain DNA-bound apo-ER in a transcriptionally silent state. Hormone would stimulate dissociation of bound repressor, freeing the LBD for binding of transcriptional intermediary factors or coactivators (32Le Douarin B. Zechel C. Garnier J.-M. Lutz Y. Tora L. Pierrat B. Heery D. Gronemeyer H. Chambon P. Losson R. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 2020-2033Crossref PubMed Scopus (576) Google Scholar, 33Cavaillès V. Dauvois S. L'Horset F. Lopez G. Hoare S. Kushner P.J. Parker M.G. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 3741-3751Crossref PubMed Scopus (673) Google Scholar, 34Onate S.A. Tsai S.Y. Tsai M.-J. O'Malley B.W. Science. 1995; 270: 1354-1357Crossref PubMed Scopus (2063) Google Scholar). In this model, antagonists would either bind the ER and not stimulate repressor dissociation, or bind, stimulate repressor dissociation, but maintain the LBD in a conformation not recognized by transcriptional intermediary factors. Repression of the ER would not only act to block the activity of the LBD but also the AF-1 domain in the N terminus, which can be activated by phosphorylation in the presence of hormone (35Ali S. Metzger D. Bornert J.-M. Chambon P. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 1153-1164Crossref PubMed Scopus (379) Google Scholar) and which has the capacity to synergize with other classes of transactivators under certain conditions (21Tora L. White J.H. Brou C. Tasset D. Webster N. Scheer E. Chambon P. Cell. 1989; 59: 477-487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (890) Google Scholar). The potential activity of AF-1 would be dampened in cells where truncated receptors lacking the LBD display significant levels of constitutive activity (36Berry M. Metzger D. Chambon P. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 2811-2818Crossref PubMed Scopus (664) Google Scholar). It is also noteworthy that aa 370-470 are adjacent to the region of the LBD (aa 300-330) identified as being important for binding of TATA box-binding protein-associated factor TAFII30, which is required for transactivation by the ER (37Jacq X. Brou C. Lutz Y. Davidson I. Chambon P. Tora L. Cell. 1994; 79: 107-117Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (344) Google Scholar). We are grateful to Drs. P. Chambon, M. Featherstone, and R. Kothary for the gifts of HEG0, 17M5TATA-luc, and p610AZ recombinants, respectively, and Drs. P. Chambon, D. Metzger, and Y. Lutz for anti-GAL and anti-ER antibodies.

The integrin αvβ6 augments the proliferation of epithelial cells in collagen gels and in vivo. This effect depends on the presence of a unique carboxyl-terminal region of the β6 subunit cytoplasmic domain. In the present study, we have utilized deletional and alanine substitution mutagenesis within this region to map the amino acids responsible for αvβ6-mediated proliferation in more detail. Replacement or deletion of any of 6 amino acids (glutamic acid 778, lysine 779, lysine 781, valine 782, aspartic acid 783, and leucine 784) largely abolished the proliferative effects of αvβ6, but none of the mutants examined interfered with αvβ6-mediated cell adhesion or with localization of αvβ6 to focal adhesions. These findings suggest that residues contained within the sequence EKXKVDL are critical for the effects of αvβ6 on proliferation in collagen gels and that pathways initiated by interaction with this sequence are distinct from those required for integrin-mediated cell attachment or focal adhesion formation. The integrin αvβ6 augments the proliferation of epithelial cells in collagen gels and in vivo. This effect depends on the presence of a unique carboxyl-terminal region of the β6 subunit cytoplasmic domain. In the present study, we have utilized deletional and alanine substitution mutagenesis within this region to map the amino acids responsible for αvβ6-mediated proliferation in more detail. Replacement or deletion of any of 6 amino acids (glutamic acid 778, lysine 779, lysine 781, valine 782, aspartic acid 783, and leucine 784) largely abolished the proliferative effects of αvβ6, but none of the mutants examined interfered with αvβ6-mediated cell adhesion or with localization of αvβ6 to focal adhesions. These findings suggest that residues contained within the sequence EKXKVDL are critical for the effects of αvβ6 on proliferation in collagen gels and that pathways initiated by interaction with this sequence are distinct from those required for integrin-mediated cell attachment or focal adhesion formation.

O-Acetylserine sulfhydrylase (OASS) is a pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP)-dependent enzyme that catalyzes the final step in the de novo synthesis of L-cysteine in Salmonella typhimurium. Complementary cofactor mutagenesis in which the active site PLP is substituted with cofactor analogs is used to test the mechanism proposed for the OASS. Data obtained with the pyridoxal 5′-deoxymethylenephosphonate-substituted enzyme suggest that the binding of OAS as it forms the external Schiff base is such that the acetate side chain is properly positioned for elimination (orthogonal to the developing α,β-double bond) only about 1% of the time. Data support the assignment of an enzyme group with a pK of 6.7 that interacts with the acetyl side chain, maintaining it orthogonal to the developing α,β-double bond. Similar studies of the 2′-methylpyridoxal 5′-phosphate-substituted enzyme suggest that, although the mechanism is identical to that catalyzed by native OASS, the reaction coordinate for α-proton abstraction may be decreased compared with that observed for the native enzyme. O-Acetylserine sulfhydrylase (OASS) is a pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP)-dependent enzyme that catalyzes the final step in the de novo synthesis of L-cysteine in Salmonella typhimurium. Complementary cofactor mutagenesis in which the active site PLP is substituted with cofactor analogs is used to test the mechanism proposed for the OASS. Data obtained with the pyridoxal 5′-deoxymethylenephosphonate-substituted enzyme suggest that the binding of OAS as it forms the external Schiff base is such that the acetate side chain is properly positioned for elimination (orthogonal to the developing α,β-double bond) only about 1% of the time. Data support the assignment of an enzyme group with a pK of 6.7 that interacts with the acetyl side chain, maintaining it orthogonal to the developing α,β-double bond. Similar studies of the 2′-methylpyridoxal 5′-phosphate-substituted enzyme suggest that, although the mechanism is identical to that catalyzed by native OASS, the reaction coordinate for α-proton abstraction may be decreased compared with that observed for the native enzyme. The biosynthesis of L-cysteine in Salmonella typhimurium proceeds via a substitution of the β-hydroxyl of L-serine with a thiol. L-Serine is first acetylated by acetyl-CoA using serine transacetylase. The O-acetyl-L-serine is formed and converted in the presence of sulfide to L-cysteine by O-acetylserine sulfhydrylase (OASS 1The abbreviations used are: OASSO-acetylserine sulfhydrylaseAATaspartate aminotransferaseDSDD-serine dehydrataseMops3-(N-morpholino)propanesulfonic acidChes2-(N-cyclohexylamino)ethanesulfonic acidMes2-(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acidTaps3-[[tris(hydroxymethyl)-methyl]-amino]propanesulfonic acidTNB5-thio-2-nitrobenzoateOASO-acetyl-L-serinePLPpyridoxal 5′-phosphatePDMPpyridoxal 5′-deoxy-methylenephosphonate2′-Me-PLP2′-methyl-PLPPDMP-AATaspartate aminotransferase reconstituted with pyridoxal 5′-deoxymethylenephosphonate. EC 4.2.99.8). The sulfhydrylase consists of two identical subunits each with 1 mol of PLP covalently bound to the protein in a Schiff base linkage (1Kredich M.N. Tomkins G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1966; 241: 4955-4965Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The native protein has a molecular mass of 68.9 kDa (2Becker M.A. Kredich N.M. Tomkins G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1969; 244: 2418-2427Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). As isolated, OASS has a visible λmax of 412 nm, while the presence of O-acetyl-L-serine results in the formation of an α-aminoacrylate intermediate absorbing at 330 and 470 nm (3Cook P.F. Hara S. Nalabolu S. Schnackerz K.D. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 2298-2303Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). The kinetic mechanism of the sulfhydrylase is BiBi ping-pong (4Cook P.F. Wedding R.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1976; 251: 2023-2029Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5Tai C.-H. Nalabolu S.R. Jacobson T.M. Minter D.E. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 6433-6442Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). A chemical mechanism has been proposed based on pH studies in which the α-amine of OAS must be unprotonated for optimum binding and formation of the external Schiff base; an enzyme group hydrogen-bonds the acetyl carbonyl to assist in the elimination of acetate, and the active site lysine that originally participated in the internal Schiff base linkage acts as a general base to abstract the α-proton (6Tai C.-H. Nalabolu S.R. Simmons III, J.W. Jacobson T.M. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 12311-12322Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). The slowest step along the reaction pathway is α-proton abstraction as determined by rapid-scanning stopped-flow experiments (7Woehl E.U. Tai C.-H. Dunn M.F. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 4776-4783Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar) and isotope effects (8Hwang C.-C. Woehl E.U. Dunn M.F. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 6358-6365Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). Several of the intermediates along the reaction pathway have been identified and characterized spectroscopically (9Schnackerz K.D. Tai C.-H. Simmons III, J.W. Jacobson T.M. Rao G.S.J. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 12125-12160Crossref Scopus (65) Google Scholar). In addition, phosphorescence has been used to probe the dynamics of the system, with several distinct conformational changes identified as reaction progress proceeds (10Strambini G.B. Cioni P. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 8392-8400Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Watanabe T. Snell E.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1972; 69: 3297-3300Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 12Schirch V. Schnackerz K.D. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Cook P.F. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1995; 324: 71-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). The aposulfhydrylase can be reconstituted with PDMP, 2′-Me-PLP, and pyridoxal 5′-sulfate. The first two cofactors produce active OASS species, whereas pyridoxal 5′-sulfate-reconstituted OASS is inactive. In this study, we make use of spectral probes and activity to study the effects of substitution of the native PLP cofactor with PDMP or 2′-Me-PLP. Spectral and kinetic properties are determined in the presence and absence of amino acid substrates and analogs and compared with those of the native enzyme to obtain further insight into the reaction pathway. Data suggest that subtle changes in the orientation of the bound cofactor can dramatically influence the activity of OASS. Results are consistent with the mechanism proposed for OASS-A (6Tai C.-H. The following timing sequence was used for the rapid scanning stopped-flow studies with PDMP-OASS, making use of a total acquisition time of 1.7 s. The 25 scans adhere to the following time points after flow is stopped: 2, 0.017 s; 4, 0.034 s; 6, 0.06 s; 8, 0.094 s; 10, 0.13 s; 12, 0.23 s; 15, 0.38 s; 20, 0.85 s; and 25, 1.7 s. The timing sequence for 2′-Me-PLP-OASS makes use of a total acquisition time of 18.7 s and the following times for the given spectra: 4, 0.034 s; 8, 0.27 s; 10, 0.425 s; 12, 0.94 s; 15, 1.7 s; 18, 4.25 s; 20, 5.95 s; 22, 11.05 s; 25, 18.7 s. Individual saturation curves for TNB and OAS obtained as a function of pH were fitted using Equation 1, whereas initial velocity patterns conforming to ping-pong and sequential kinetic mechanism were fitted using Equations 2 and 3, respectively. v=VA/(Ka+A)(Eq. 1) v=VAB/(KaB+KbA+AB)(Eq. 2) v=VAB/(KiaKb+KaB+KbA+AB)(Eq. 3) In Equations 1, 2, 3 v and V are initial and maximum velocities, respectively, A and B are reactant concentrations, Ka and Kb are Michaelis constants for A and B, respectively, and Kia is the inhibition constant for A. Data for the first order plots of ln A470 versus time used to quantitate deacetylase activity were fitted using the equation for a straight line, and the pH dependence of the first order rate constant was fitted using Equation 4. Data for the pH dependence of the log V/KTNB for 2′-Me-PLP-OASS which decreases at high and low pH with limiting slopes of −1 and 1, respectively, were fit using Equation 5.log y = log(C/[H/K1])(Eq. 4) log y = log(C/[1 + H/K1 + K2/H])(Eq. 5) In Equations 4 and 5, y is the observed value of the parameter at any pH, C is its pH-independent value, H is the hydrogen ion concentration, K1 and K2 are the estimated pK values for functional groups on reactant or enzyme. If the intermediate F, generated as a result of transfer of part of A to enzyme in a ping-pong kinetic mechanism, is unstable, the initial velocity pattern obtained in the absence of added inhibitors will intersect to the left of the ordinate, mimicking a sequential kinetic mechanism. Consider Mechanism 6 below where the intermediate F is converted to E at a rate within the time scale of the steady state assay. Derivation of the rate equation for the above was carried out using the method of King and Altman (25King E.L. Altman C. J. Phys. Chem. 1956; 60: 1375-1378Crossref Scopus (752) Google Scholar). The distribution equations for the enzyme forms depicted in Mechanism E6 are as follows: E/Et=k7k9Bk2+k3+k5k8+k9k2+k3/Δ(Eq. 7) EA/Et=k1k5Ak8+k9+k1k7k9AB/Δ(Eq. 8) F/Et=k1k3Ak8+k9/Δ(Eq. 9) FB/Et=k1k3k7AB/Δ(Eq. 10) where Δ is equal to the sum of all of the numerator terms in Equations 7, 8, 9, 10. The initial rate is defined as in Equation 11. v=k9[FB](Eq. 11) Substituting for FB and Δ gives Equation 12. v=k1k3k7k9ABEt/[k5(k8+k9)(k2+k3)+k1A(k8+k9)(k3+k5)+k7k9B(k2+k3)+k1k7AB(k3+k9)](Eq. 12) Note that unlike the normal rate equation for a ping-pong kinetic mechanism, the denominator of the rate equation includes a constant term. Expressions for the kinetic parameters (V/Et)′, (V/KaEt)′, (V/KbEt)′, and V/KiaKbEt are given in Equations 13, 14, 15, 16. For comparison, the same parameters obtained for a ping-pong mechanism in which F is stable on the steady state time scale are provided in italics (the ′ is used to distinguish the rate constants obtained for Mechanism 6). (In all cases, the parameters obtained for Mechanism 6 reduce to those in italics when k5 is set equal to 0.)V/Et′=k3k9/k3+k9 V/Et=k3k9/k3+k9(Eq. 13) V/KaEt′=k1k3/k2+k3 V/KaEt=k1k3/k2+k3(Eq. 14) V/KbEt′=k3k7k9/k8+k9k3+k5 V/KbEt=k7k9/k8+k9(Eq. 15) V/KiaKibEt=k1k3k7k9/k5k8+k9k2+k3 None(Eq. 16) The difference between the two mechanisms lies in the rate constant for the second half-reaction, V/KbEt, and the presence of the V/KiaKbEt term. The rate of the first half-reaction at limiting A is unaffected, since k5 occurs after release of the first product. In addition, V is unaffected, since at an infinite concentration of B, no F is present. The rate of the second half-reaction at limiting B, however, is affected since the amount of F present to combine with B depends on the rate of conversion of F to E via the step represented by k5. The V/KiaKbEt term, on closer inspection, is the product of the V/K values for a ping-pong mechanism with stable F (italic Equations 14 and 15), divided by the rate constant for leakage of F to E. The constant term thus reflects the decrease in the rate when both reactants are limiting as a result of the step denoted by k5 continually regenerating E. As a result, an E term is effectively generated in the denominator of the rate equation in addition to the that represented by the V/Ka in a normal ping-pong mechanism. The product of the (V/K)′ values divided by V/KiaKbEt effectively subtracts out the rate of the normal ping-pong reaction giving the maximum rate of the deacetylase reaction.[(V/KaEt)′][(V/KbEt)′]/[V/KiaKbEt]=Vdeacetylase/Et=k3k5/(k3+k5)(Eq. 17) It is also instructive to look at the expressions for the Michaelis constants. The ratio of V and the V/K of each of the reactants gives the following expressions for the Km values. (Ka)′=Kia(1+k3/k2)(1+k3/k9)Ka=Kia(1+k3/k2)/(1+K3/K9)(Eq. 18) (Kb)′=Kib[(1+k9/k8)/(1+k3/k9)](k3+k5)/k9; Kb=Kib(1+k9/k8)/(1+K3/K9)(Eq. 19) where Kia and Kib are k2/k1 and k8/k7, respectively. As expected, it is Kb that is affected, modified by the ratio (k3+ k5)/k9, and since k5 must, by definition be of the same order of magnitude as k3, k9, (Kb)′ will be greater than Kb. The PDMP-reconstituted OASS-A (PDMP-OASS) is bright yellow-green in color and exhibits a typical PLP enzyme spectrum as shown in Fig. 1A. Addition of 1 mM OAS results in a decrease in the absorbance at 280 and 418 nm, concomitant with the appearance of new bands at <250, 330 and 478 nm, respectively. The latter two bands signal formation of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate (2Becker M.A. Kredich N.M. Tomkins G.M. J. Biol. Dunn M.F. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 6358-6365Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). Since it is difficult to maintain TNB saturating because of its high extinction coefficient, and data for both enzymes adhere to a ping-pong kinetic mechanism below 6.5, data were collected at pH 6.09, where values of 1.4 ± 0.2 and 4.7 ± 0.3 were obtained for D(V/KOAS) for PDMP- and 2′-Me-PLP-OASS-A, respectively. Values of 4.3 ± 0.4 and 4.7 ± 0.7 for D(V/KOAS) were also obtained for 2′-Me-PLP-OASS-A at pH 7.02 and 6.47. The secondary deuterium isotope effect measured for PDMP-OASS-A with OAS-3,3-d2 at pH 6.09 is 0.92 ± 0.10 with TNB as the nucleophilic substrate and 0.95 ± 0.03 with sulfide as the substrate, whereas the secondary isotope effect obtained for 2′-Me-PLP-OASS-A at pH 6.09 is 1.12 ± 0.06. Reactions of PDMP-OASS-A with OAS are shown in Fig. 6A, where spectrum 0 is the spectrum for enzyme prior to adding OAS. Upon addition of OAS, the 418-nm absorption band of the free PDMP enzyme resulting from the internal Schiff base (3Cook P.F. Hara S. Nalabolu S. Schnackerz K.D. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 2298-2303Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) is shifted slightly to higher wavelength as seen in the value of the λmax for spectra 6-10 versus spectrum 0, and the lack of a single isosbestic point for the spectra 0-10. The rapid shift in the wavelength reflecting formation of the external Schiff base of OAS (9Schnackerz K.D. Tai C.-H. Simmons III, J.W. Jacobson T.M. Rao G.S.J. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 12125-12160Crossref Scopus (65) Google Scholar) is followed by a decrease in the absorbance at 418-425 with the concomitant appearance of new bands at 330 and 478 nm resulting from formation of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate. Spectrum 25 shows the equilibrium mixture of species after reaction for about 1.7 s. Changes observed at 470 nm give an estimated rate constant of 5 s−1 for formation of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate. The α-aminoacrylate intermediate builds up as the product of the first half-reaction in the absence of the second product, TNB or sulfide. Addition of the second substrate results in a rapid bleaching of the 330- and 470-nm bands (7Woehl E.U. Tai C.-H. Dunn M.F. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 4776-4783Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Reactions of 2′-Me-PLP-OASS-A with OAS are shown in Fig. 6B and are qualitatively identical to those shown for PDMP-OASS-A. Spectrum 0 shows mainly the free enzyme absorbing maximally at 412 nm, and spectrum 25 shows the equilibrium mixture of species after reaction for about 18.7 s. The reaction is slow because the concentration of OAS is well below the Km for OAS which is ≥10 mM. There are several pieces of information that indicate how substitution of PDMP for PLP has changed the mechanism of the OASS-A. The V/Et for PDMP-OASS has decreased 100-fold relative to native enzyme using TNB as the nucleophilic substrate, while V/KOAS has decreased only by a factor of 5. Nonetheless, the rapid scanning stopped-flow studies indicate that, just as for native enzyme, the abstraction of the α-proton is rate-determining, and primary and secondary deuterium kinetic isotope effects suggest that the transition state for α-proton abstraction may even be slightly earlier than that of the native enzyme, which exhibits an intrinsic primary deuterium isotope effect of 2.8 and a β-secondary deuterium isotope effect of 1.1 (8Hwang C.-C. Woehl E.U. Dunn M.F. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 6358-6365Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). (The observed isotope effects are intrinsic based on the pH dependence of the isotope effects and the demonstrated rate-limitation of α-proton abstraction of the cofactor-substituted enzymes.) Thus, there appears to be only about 1% of the external Schiff base of OAS that is able at any given time to produce the α-aminoacrylate intermediate, in equilibrium with 99% that is not capable of undergoing the α,β-elimination reaction at a given time. 2The assumption is made that the concerted α,β-elimination is synchronous, i.e. that Cβ-O bond cleavage occurs at the same time and to the same extent as Cα-H bond cleavage. The latter is a reasonable assumption if the acetate leaving group is held orthogonal to the forming α,β-double bond, and there is no quinonoid. In support of the lack of quinonoid, the pyridinium nitrogen of the coenzyme is unprotonated and hydrogen-bonded to an enzyme serine, suggesting that the pyridinium does not play a Lewis acid role (P. Burkhard and J. N. Jansonius, unpublished). Leaving group oxygen-18 isotope effects are planned to further define the α,β-elimination reaction. If the transition state is earlier for the PDMP enzyme based on the assumed synchronous concerted reaction, the above data suggest that the α,β-elimination reaction of PDMP-OASS is perhaps even more facile than that catalyzed by native OASS. (Even if the reaction is not completely synchronous it is unlikely to affect the interpretation significantly.) The remaining question is why only 1% of the OAS external Schiff base is converted to product at any given time? The answer likely lies in the only difference between the pH profiles for the PDMP-OASS and the native enzyme, i.e. the lack of a pH dependence of the V/K for OAS at low pH. The mechanism proposed for OASS-A is shown in Scheme 1. The group that interacts with the acetyl side chain of OAS has a pK of about 6.7 in native OASS-A and has been proposed to act by holding acetate orthogonal to the plane of the aldimine, facilitating β-elimination (6Tai C.-H. Nalabolu S.R. Simmons III, J.W. Jacobson T.M. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 12311-12322Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). The inability of the group to carry out its function in the PDMP-OASS reaction may allow the side chain to be in all orientations, being properly positioned for elimination only 1% of the time. Eventually all of the external Schiff base will produce the α-aminoacrylate intermediate, but only 1% at any given time. Data obtained with the PDMP-OASS-A thus support the role proposed for the enzyme group with a pK of 6.5. The above enzyme group must also be protonated for the second half-reaction and is observed in the V/KTNB pH profile of the PDMP-OASS. Therefore, the second half-reaction likely functions in a manner similar to that of native OASS-A. Finally, the pK of the active site lysine (determined from the pH dependence of the deacetylase activity (3Cook P.F. Hara S. Nalabolu S. Schnackerz K.D. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 2298-2303Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar)) that acts as a general base in the α,β-elimination reaction is within error identical for PDMP-OASS and native enzyme. The 2′-Me-PLP-OASS is kinetically similar to the native enzyme. Although the enzyme still utilizes TNB effectively, the natural reaction with OAS and sulfide is now very poor with V/K values 3 orders of magnitude lower than those of the native enzyme. The difference in the utilization of the bulky aromatic TNB and of the smaller sulfide indicates a change in the binding sites for the two nucleophilic substrates. The decrease in steady state rate discussed above is accompanied by an increase in the primary deuterium isotope effect from a value of 2.8 for the native enzyme to a value of 4.5 for 2′-Me-PLP-OASS. The primary deuterium effect is pH-independent from 6.09 to 7.02. In the case of native OASS-A, the V/KOAS decreases below pH 7 (6Tai C.-H. Nalabolu S.R. Simmons III, J.W. Jacobson T.M. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 12311-12322Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar), while the value of D(V/KOAS) increases from a value of 1.7 to a value of 2.8 over the same pH range (8Hwang C.-C. Woehl E.U. Dunn M.F. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 6358-6365Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). The latter indicates that OAS is sticky, 3A sticky substrate is one for which the EA complex favors product formation as opposed to dissociation to free substrate. while the lack of a pH dependence of D(V/KOAS) for the 2′-Me-PLP enzyme indicates that it is not. In agreement with the latter conclusion, rapid-scanning stopped-flow data exhibit a slow formation of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate from the rapidly formed external Schiff base. The secondary isotope effect utilizing OAS-3,3-d2, however, is only 1.1, indicating an early transition state for α-proton abstraction, assuming a synchronous concerted mechanism (8Hwang C.-C. Woehl E.U. Dunn M.F. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 6358-6365Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). The difference in primary intrinsic deuterium isotope effects of 2.8 for the native enzyme and 4.5 for the 2′-Me-PLP enzyme reflects either a difference in the amount of hydrogen tunneling, nature of the transition state, or both. Since the secondary isotope effect is identical to that obtained for the native enzyme, the increase in the primary deuterium isotope effect likely reflects an increase in hydrogen tunneling resulting from a decrease in the length of the reaction coordinate. The latter may be brought about by a steric effect of the 2′-methyl group of the cofactor, and this aspect is now being investigated. As discussed under “Results,” initial velocity patterns measured for the PDMP enzyme depend on the pH at which it is measured. Above pH 6, the initial velocity pattern intersects to the left of the ordinate, while at pH 6 the pattern is parallel, consistent with the proposed ping-pong mechanism (4Cook P.F. Wedding R.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1976; 251: 2023-2029Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5Tai C.-H. Nalabolu S.R. Jacobson T.M. Minter D.E. Cook P.F. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 6433-6442Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). The intersecting initial velocity pattern is indicative of a rapid deacetylase activity for the PDMP-OASS-A relative to the net rate constant for the second half-reaction at limiting concentrations of TNB. As the pH decreases, the rate constant for the deacetylase decreases below a pK of 7.9, and at pH 6 is no longer significant with respect to the rate of the second half-reaction. A calculation of the maximum rate constant for the deacetylase activity, k3k5/(k3+ k5) according to Equation 17, gives values that range from 0.008 to 0.012 s−1 at pH 7. The rate constant k5, which reflects the deacetylase activity, has a pH-independent value of 0.01 s−1, which would give a value of 0.001 s−1 at pH 7. Data would thus suggest that the maximum rate of the deacetylase reaction, obtained by definition at limiting TNB concentration, is limited by the rate of breakdown of F (the α-aminoacrylate intermediate) to pyruvate and ammonia, which is k5. In agreement with the suggested limitation by k5, k3 is estimated at about 5 s−1 from rapid-scanning stopped-flow studies. The latter allows a determination of the rate-limiting step in the overall reaction of OAS and TNB to give acetate and S-CNP-L-cysteine, given by Equation 13, k3k9/(k3+ k9), and estimated as 0.005 s−1, Table I. Since k3 is 5 s−1, k9 must be 0.005 s−1, the limiting step for the overall reaction, which includes nucleophilic attack by TNB on the α-aminoacrylate intermediate to form the S-CNP-cysteine external Schiff base and release of the product amino acid, Scheme 1. It is likely the former that limits the overall rate. Based on the above considerations, the V/K for the second half-reaction given by Equation 15 reduces to k9/KiTNB, where KiTNB is k8/k7. Thus, the deacetylase activity will be important even at the highest concentrations used in these studies (1/6 the Km value for TNB), which gives a value of 0.0008 s−1 compared with the effective value of 0.001 s−1 for the deacetylase rate. The absorbance, fluorescence, and CD spectral properties of the PDMP-OASS are remarkably similar to those of the native enzyme. Data suggest that the gross structure (far UV CD and intrinsic Trp fluorescence) of the cofactor-substituted enzyme and the general symmetry of the bound cofactor (visible CD) are for all intents and purposes identical to those of native (PLP) OASS-A. In addition, the UV-visible absorbance and cofactor fluorescence spectra are qualitatively identical to those of native enzyme. There are slight differences in the extinction coefficients of the spectral bands in the absence and presence of OAS in the PDMP-OASS that indicate a change in the equilibrium distribution of Schiff base tautomers, Table I.

We previously identified a B-cell-specific regulatory element in the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) enhancer, π, with striking similarity to binding sites for ets-related transcription factors. Whereas the ability of ets-related factors to bind to and transactivate the π site has been substantiated, the identification of the particular member of the ets family responsible for B-cell-specific regulation of the π site has remained controversial. We have used antibodies specific for individual members of the ets family to evaluate which ets-related factor in B-cell nuclear extracts interacts with the IgH π site. We present strong evidence that ELF-1 is highly expressed in B-cells and is one of two major factors specifically interacting with the murine IgH enhancer π site in B-cell nuclear extracts. Binding of ELF-1 correlates with activity of the π site, since mutations abolishing function of π also inhibit binding of ELF-1. Furthermore, we demonstrate that ELF-1 can transactivate the IgH enhancer in HeLa cells, suggesting a role for ELF-1 in B-cell-specific IgH gene expression. We previously identified a B-cell-specific regulatory element in the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) enhancer, π, with striking similarity to binding sites for ets-related transcription factors. Whereas the ability of ets-related factors to bind to and transactivate the π site has been substantiated, the identification of the particular member of the ets family responsible for B-cell-specific regulation of the π site has remained controversial. We have used antibodies specific for individual members of the ets family to evaluate which ets-related factor in B-cell nuclear extracts interacts with the IgH π site. We present strong evidence that ELF-1 is highly expressed in B-cells and is one of two major factors specifically interacting with the murine IgH enhancer π site in B-cell nuclear extracts. Binding of ELF-1 correlates with activity of the π site, since mutations abolishing function of π also inhibit binding of ELF-1. Furthermore, we demonstrate that ELF-1 can transactivate the IgH enhancer in HeLa cells, suggesting a role for ELF-1 in B-cell-specific IgH gene expression.

Abstract Mouse P19 embryonal carcinoma cells in aggregation culture in the presence of 10−6 M retinoic acid followed by monolayer culture differentiate into nerve and glial cells. In this study, we demonstrated that the neurofilament-L (NF-L) mRNA and protein levels of these cells were enhanced in accordance with their retinoic acid-induced neural differentiation. Okadaic acid (OA) treatment of the cells markedly suppressed this differentiation-dependent NF-L gene expression increase and neurite outgrowth of the cells. Similar results were obtained when tautomycin was used instead of OA, suggesting that inhibition of protein phosphatase(s) is involved in the suppression of neural differentiation. OA treatment did not affect the NF-L gene transcription level, determined by the nuclear run-on transcription assay, but it did reduce the stability of both the 3.5- and 2.3-kilobase NF-L mRNAs. The expression and activity levels of protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) and 2B (PP2B) but not protein phosphatase 1 (PP1) in P19 cells increased in accordance with the enhanced NF-L gene expression. The presence of OA in the culture medium during the course of the neural differentiation caused a reduced PP2A activity but not PP1 and PP2B activities of the cell extracts. On the other hand, both PP1 and PP2B activities but not PP2A activity of cell extracts were suppressed by the addition of cyclosporin A or FK506 in the culture medium. However, both cyclosporin A and FK506 treatments affected neither NF-L gene expression nor neurite outgrowth. These results demonstrate that the OA treatment inhibits the differentiation-dependent increase in NF-L gene expression by destabilizing its mRNAs and suggest that PP2A plays key roles in the differentiation-dependent enhanced expression of the NF-L gene and is the point of the action of OA.

Doxycycline, a member of the tetracycline family, has been shown to reduce a type X collagen epitope as detected by immunohistochemistry with a monoclonal antibody in an avian explant culture system (1Cole A.A. Chubinskaya S. Luchene L.J. Chlebek K. Orth M.W. Greenwald R.A. Kuettner K.E. Schmid T.M. Arthritis Rheum. 1994; 37: 1727-1734Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). It was also shown to decrease collagenase and gelatinase activities and thus matrix degradation. This study investigates the effect of doxycycline on type X collagen synthesis in monolayer cultures of hypertrophic chondrocytes. Protein synthesis was evaluated by radioisotopic labeling during doxycycline, tetracycline, or minocycline treatment. Radiolabeled proteins were analyzed by gel electrophoresis, and total collagen was quantitated by hydroxyproline analysis. Additionally, the synthesis of type X collagen was measured by immunoprecipitation. Doxycycline was found to inhibit type X production more effectively than either of the other tetracyclines at comparable dose levels. Furthermore, type X collagen was inhibited more than other collagens, non-collagenous proteins and proteoglycans, with maximal inhibition at 80 μg/ml and an IC50 of 7 μg/ml. This inhibition by doxycycline was specific for type X collagen at 10 μg/ml, and the pattern was distinct from cycloheximide, a recognized inhibitor of protein translation. This suppression of type X collagen could not be overcome by excess extracellular calcium, conditions that have been demonstrated to induce synthesis of this protein (2Bonen D.K. Schmid T.M. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115: 1171-1178Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). A C terminus truncated soybean 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid (ACC) synthase (466 aa) was fused to an N terminus truncated tomato ACC oxidase (312 aa) to create a 778-amino acid fusion polypeptide. This ACC synthase-ACC oxidase fusion enzyme (ACSO) was expressed in a heterologous prokaryotic Escherichia coli system, which is capable of converting endogenous S-adenosyl-L-methionine (AdoMet) to ethylene. The molecular weight of the fusion enzyme, ACSO, as determined by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, was 90 ± 3 kDa. Gel filtration analysis indicates that the native ACSO is oligomeric and is capable of converting exogenously supplied AdoMet to ethylene. The ethylene production rate of ACSO fusion enzyme was determined to be 6.0 nmol h−1 mg−1 under our assaying conditions using the partially purified enzyme extract. In the enzyme reaction mixture, an increase in ethylene production catalyzed by the bifunctional ACSO was accompanied by a decrease in ACC accumulation. Similarly, in E. coli cells, the level of ACC, produced as an intermediate during the sequential reactions from AdoMet to ethylene, was also found to arise earlier than that of ethylene. Because ACSO could produce ethylene from the ubiquitous AdoMet in living cell and the method commonly used to measure gaseous ethylene is simple, fast, and sensitive, we anticipate this bifunctional fusion enzyme to be useful as a reporter and for research in molecular biology, developmental biology, fermentation, and genetic engineering. This ACC synthase-ACC oxidase fusion enzyme (ACSO) was expressed in a heterologous prokaryotic Escherichia coli system, which is capable of converting endogenous S-adenosyl-L-methionine (AdoMet) to ethylene. Ethylene, a simple organic molecule with complex biological function, has profound and versatile effects on the growth and development of higher plants. These effects include promoting fruit ripening, flower senescence, and petal and leaf abscissions, inhibiting seedling elongation, stimulating root initiation, promoting initiation of the flowering of pineapples, and increasing latex flow in rubber trees (for review, see 1Lieberman M. Annu. Rev. Plant Physiol. 1979; 30: 533-591Crossref Google Scholar and 2Yang S.F. Hoffman N.E. Annu. Rev. Plant Physiol. 1984; 35: 155-189Crossref Google Scholar). To manipulate the extent of the ethylene effect on these agricultural and horticultural crops, many registered chemical compounds such as aminoethoxyvinylglycine (an inhibitor of ethylene biosynthesis), silver thiosulfate (an inhibitor of ethylene action), and ethephon (an ethylene-releasing compound), were developed (3Maynard J.A. Swan J.M. Aust. J. Chem. 1963; 16: 596-608Crossref Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 4Owens L.D. Lieberman M. Kunishi A. Plant Physiol. 1971; 48: 1-4Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Exogenous application of these chemicals onto crops of commercial value have been shown to increase the productivity and quality (5Abeles F.B. Morgan P.W. Saltveit Jr., M.E. Ethylene in Plant Biology. 2nd Ed. Academic Press, Inc., San Diego, CA1992Google Scholar). However, elucidation of the ethylene biosynthesis pathway in higher plants and recent successful cloning of the key genes involved in the ethylene biosynthesis have offered a good opportunity to either enhance or repress endogenous ethylene production via genetic engineering. Ethylene is synthesized through the ACC 1The abbreviations used are: ACC1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acidACSOACC synthase-ACC oxidase hybrid enzymeaaamino acidAdoMetS-adenosyl-L-methionineNi2+-NTAnickel-nitrilotriacetic acidPCRpolymerase chain reactionPLPpyridoxal 5′-phosphatePAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresiskbkilobase(s).-dependent pathway in higher plants (6Adams D.O. Yang S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 170-174Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Continued production of ethylene via this pathway is sustained by replenishing the AdoMet via the methionine cycle at the expense of ATP (2Yang S.F. Hoffman N.E. Annu. Rev. Plant Physiol. 1984; 35: 155-189Crossref Google Scholar). The two key enzymes catalyzing the formation of ethylene from AdoMet are ACC synthase (S-adenosyl-L-methionine methylthioadenosine-lyase, EC 4.4.1.14) and ACC oxidase (7Boller T. Herner R.C. Kende H. Planta. 1979; 145: 293-303Crossref PubMed Scopus (340) Google Scholar, 8Yu Y. Adams A.D. Yang S.F. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1979; 198: 280-286Crossref PubMed Scopus (226) Google Scholar, 9Ververidis P. John P. Phytochemistry. 1991; 30: 725-727Crossref Scopus (221) Google Scholar, 10Dong J.G. Ferná;ndez-Maculet C.J. Yang S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9789-9793Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). Genes encoding the two key enzymes have recently been cloned (11Sato T. Theologis A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 6621-6625Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar, 12Hamilton A.J. Lycett G.W. Grierson D. Nature. 1990; 346: 284-287Crossref Scopus (605) Google Scholar, 13Nakajima N. Mori H. Yamazaki K. Imaseki H. Plant Cell Physiol. 1990; 31: 1021-1029Google Scholar, 14Van der Straeten D. Van Wiemeersch L. Goodman H.M. Van Montagu M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4859-4863Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar) and expressed in heterologous systems as functional enzymes (11Sato T. Theologis A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 6621-6625Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar, 13Nakajima N. Mori H. Yamazaki K. Imaseki H. Plant Cell Physiol. 1990; 31: 1021-1029Google Scholar, 15Li N. Wiesman Z. Liu D. Mattoo A.K. FEBS Lett. 1992; 306: 103-107Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar, 16White M.F. Vasquez J. Yang S.F. Kirsch J.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 12428-12432Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar, 17Hamilton A.J. Bouzayen M. Grierson D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 7434-7437Crossref PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar, 18Zhang Z. Schofield C.J. Baldwin J.E. Thomas P. John P. Biochem. J. 1995; 307: 77-85Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). The expression of both genes is regulated developmentally and environmentally (19Kende H. Annu. Rev. Plant Physiol. Plant Mol. Biol. 1993; 44: 283-307Crossref Scopus (1018) Google Scholar). To produce ethylene via AdoMet in a concerted fashion, we chose to construct an artificial bifunctional enzyme (ACSO) by in-frame fusion of ACC synthase and ACC oxidase because genetic fusion as a means of creating bi- or multifunctional enzymes has commonly been used to study some of the fundamental problems in biology (20Champe S.P. Benzer S. J. Mol. Biol. 1962; 4: 288-292Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 21Silhavy T.J. Beckwith J.R. Microbiol. Rev. 1985; 49: 398-418Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The hybrid enzymes sometimes demonstrated the superiority over two individual native enzymes catalyzing the same multistep sequential reaction (22Bülow L. Mosbach K. Trends Biotechnol. 1991; 9: 226-231Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). In the cases of plant molecular biology, the Escherichia coli β-glucuronidase (gus), a commonly used scorable marker (23Jefferson R.A. Kavanagh T.A. Bevan M.W. EBMO J. 1987; 6: 3901-3907Crossref PubMed Scopus (8035) Google Scholar), was fused to some efficient selectable markers such as neomycin phosphotransferase (npt II) or metallothionein protein to produce an ideal scorable as well as selectable artificial bifunctional marker (24Datla R.S.S. Hammerlindl J.K. Pelcher L.E. Crosby W.L. Selvaraj G. Gene (Amst.). 1991; 101: 239-246Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 25Elmayan T. Tepfer M. Plant J. 1994; 6: 433-440Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar). 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid ACC synthase-ACC oxidase hybrid enzyme amino acid S-adenosyl-L-methionine nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid polymerase chain reaction pyridoxal 5′-phosphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis kilobase(s). The primers, PACS1 (5′-GAC C ATATG GGG TTG ATG GAT GTG G-3′) and PACS2 (5′AAA GGATCC TCA AAT TGT GGC TTT AAC CAG AGG-3′), corresponding to nucleotides 157-181 and 1594-1618 of soybean ACC synthase cDNA (GMCACCS1; accession number X67100; 26Liu D. Li N. Dube S. Kalinski A. Herman E. Mattoo A.K. Plant Cell Physiol. 1993; 34: 1151-1157Google Scholar), respectively, and two additional primers, PACO1 (5′-ATT C AT ATG GAT AT C TTC CCA ATT ATT AAC TTG-3′) and PACO2 (5′-CGA GGATCC TTA AGC ACT TGC AAT TTG ATC A-3′), corresponding to nucleotides 166-198 and 1098-1119 of tomato ACC oxidase cDNA (LEETHYBR or pCR13; accession number X04792; 17Hamilton A.J. Bouzayen M. Grierson D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 7434-7437Crossref PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar), respectively, were synthesized using an automated DNA synthesizer, Gene Assembler (Pharmacia). A NdeI site (underlined) was introduced into PACS1 and PACO1 primers, and a BamHI (underlined) site into PACS2 and PACO2 primers. An EcoRV site (underlined) was also introduced into the PACO1 primer downstream of the NdeI site only for fusion of the N terminus of ACC oxidase to the C terminus of ACC synthase. Both soybean plant and tomato fruit cDNA libraries used in this experiment were made by Stratagene. The DNA fragments amplified from PCR were cloned as described previously (15Li N. Wiesman Z. Liu D. Mattoo A.K. FEBS Lett. 1992; 306: 103-107Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar) and sequenced by the dideoxynucleotide method described by Sanger (27Sanger F. Science. 1981; 214: 1205-1210Crossref PubMed Scopus (444) Google Scholar) using double-strand recombinant plasmid DNA as the template. The concentration of a protein extract was determined by the Bradford method (28Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-258Crossref PubMed Scopus (209479) Google Scholar), using bovine serum albumin as standard. The Laemmli method (29Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (204700) Google Scholar) was used for SDS-PAGE analysis of protein samples. The fractionated proteins on SDS-PAGE were visualized either by Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250 staining or by silver staining (30Wray W. Boulikes T. Wray V.P. Hancock R. Anal. Biochem. 1981; 118: 197-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (2491) Google Scholar). The unstained gels were electrotransferred onto nitrocellulose membranes. The Western blot was then treated both with alkaline phosphatase-conjugated Ni2+-NTA (a product of Qiagen Inc., Chatsworth, CA) and the primary polyclonal antibody (a gift from Dr. J. C. Pech, ENSA, Toulouse, France) raised against a tomato ACC oxidase (pCR13). The colorimetric detection of Ni2+-NTA/alkaline phosphatase-treated blots were performed in the presence of the alkaline phosphatase substrate 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl phosphate/nitro blue tetrazolium. The immunodetection of the primary antibody-treated Western blots was carried out using the alkaline phosphatase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG (H + L) as the secondary antibody. Expression of the fusion enzyme in E. coli was achieved through the pET system (Novagen, Madison, WI) previously described by Studier et al. (31Studier F.W. Rosenberg A.A. Dunn J.J. Dubendorff J.W. Methods Enzymol. 1990; 185: 60-89Crossref PubMed Scopus (5973) Google Scholar). The frozen cells were resuspended in the enzyme extraction buffer described by Dong et al. (10Dong J.G. Ferná;ndez-Maculet C.J. Yang S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9789-9793Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). Cells were lysed by sonication on ice and centrifuged for 20 min at 15,000 × g at 4°C to remove cell debris. The crude cell-free protein extract was filtered through 0.22-μm low-binding Millex®-GV filter (Millipore) before it was used for further purification and/or for the bifunctional enzyme activities assay. The cell-free enzyme extract (0.25 ml) or the enzyme extract (0.25 ml) purified through an ion-exchange column, Mono Q HR 5/5 (32Li N. Mattoo A.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6908-6917Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), was loaded onto a gel filtration column consisting of two consecutively linked Superose-12 HR 10/30 columns (32Li N. Mattoo A.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6908-6917Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The column was mounted onto a medium-pressure fast protein liquid chromatography system (Bio-Rad Laboratories) and run at a flow rate of 0.2 ml/min. The column was calibrated using the native protein markers and blue dextran (2,000 kDa) purchased from the Pharmacia. A molecular mass standard curve was established using the semilog method based on data obtained from the gel filtration analysis of the molecular mass markers. The ACC synthase and ACC oxidase activity assays were performed according to the methods described previously (7Boller T. Herner R.C. Kende H. Planta. 1979; 145: 293-303Crossref PubMed Scopus (340) Google Scholar, 8Yu Y. Adams A.D. Yang S.F. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1979; 198: 280-286Crossref PubMed Scopus (226) Google Scholar, 9Ververidis P. John P. Phytochemistry. 1991; 30: 725-727Crossref Scopus (221) Google Scholar, 10Dong J.G. Ferná;ndez-Maculet C.J. Yang S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9789-9793Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar, 33Lizada M.C.C. Yang S.F. Anal. Biochem. 1979; 100: 140-145Crossref PubMed Scopus (883) Google Scholar). Bifunction of the ACSO fusion enzyme is defined as the catalytic activities of both ACC synthase and ACC oxidase present in the same fusion polypeptide. The bifunctional activities of the fusion enzyme were assayed with 10 to 200 μl of the crude or Mono Q column-purified enzyme extract. The reaction was performed at 30°C for 30 min with constant shaking in a 4-ml test tube, which contained, in a total volume of 0.5 ml, 20 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.6), 1 mM dithiothreitol, 20 μM PLP, 30 mM sodium ascorbate, 20 mM sodium bicarbonate, 20 μM ferrous sulfate, and 20% glycerol. To make a hybrid enzyme possessing both ACC synthase and ACC oxidase activities, we selected a soybean ACC synthase and a tomato ACC oxidase as the constituents of this hybrid enzyme. Soybean ACC synthase cDNA (GMCACCS1) and tomato ACC oxidase cDNA (LEETHYBR or pCR13) were prepared by PCR. The 1.5-kb PCR product coding for the 484-aa long soybean ACC synthase was first cloned into the 3.9-kb pCR™ II cloning vector (Invitrogen BV, The Netherlands). This chimeric plasmid DNA was then digested by restriction enzymes, EcoRV and BamHI. A 54-nucleotide DNA fragment was cleaved from the 3′ end of the ACC synthase cDNA, which resulted in the deletion of 18 aa from the C terminus of ACC synthase. This double-digested chimeric DNA plasmid DNA was then ligated to a 0.9-kb DNA fragment encoding tomato ACC oxidase and treated with the same two restriction enzymes. This recombinant DNA plasmid (6.25 kb) was then double-digested by NdeI and BamHI. The resultant 2.35-kb recombinant DNA encoding the C-terminal truncated soybean ACC synthase (aa 1-466) and the N-terminal truncated tomato ACC oxidase (aa 4-316) was inserted into an expression vector, pET14b (Novagen, Madison, WI) (Fig. 1A), pretreated with NdeI and BamHI. This insertion created a fusion of a short polypeptide with an array of 6 histidines, His-tag (34Smith M.C. Furman T.C. Ingolia C. Pidgeon C. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 7211-7215Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), attached to the N terminus of the hybrid enzyme created by the first fusion of soybean ACC synthase and tomato ACC oxidase (Fig. 1A). The E. coli, BL21(DE3), harboring the pET14b-ACSO chimeric plasmid expressed a 90 ± -kDa fusion polypeptide, as determined by SDS-PAGE and Western blot (Fig. 1B), which was consistent with the expected size of the fusion enzyme (87.8 kDa) calculated from the fusion protein primary sequence. Aside from the dominant form (>90%) of the intact His-tagged ACSO fusion enzyme detected in the crude extract, three minor polypeptides of smaller size were also observed (Fig. 1B). The crude E. coli fusion protein extract possesses both ACC synthase (46 nmol h−1 mg−1) and ACC oxidase activities (0.4 nmol h−1 mg−1). The level of ACSO expression in E. coli was estimated to be less than 1%. Because of the presence of some smaller size polypeptides in the ACSO enzyme extract cross-reacting with the His-tag-binding Ni2+-NTA/alkaline phosphatase conjugate (Fig. 1B, lane 4), the bifunctional activities detected in the crude fusion protein extract could come either from the intact fusion enzyme or from the proteolytically cleaved ACSO fusion enzymes. Using the Mono Q column, the three polypeptides of smaller sizes cross-reacting with Ni2+-NTA/alkaline phosphatase conjugate were removed (Fig. 1B, lane 5). To verify that both ACC synthase and ACC oxidase activities found in the fusion enzyme crude extract were actually from the 90-kDa fusion enzyme, the fusion enzyme in the crude enzyme extract was further analyzed using a gel filtration column (see “Experimental Procedures”). Each fraction (0.4 ml) was assayed for both ACC synthase and ACC oxidase activity. It was found that both ACC synthase and ACC oxidase activities peaked at the same elution position (Fig. 2A). The specific activity of ACC synthase and ACC oxidase in the peak fraction were determined to be 9.9 μmol h−1 mg−1 and 6.0 nmol h−1 mg−1, respectively. The ACC synthase and ACC oxidase specific activity of the partially enriched fusion enzyme increased 214- and 15-fold, respectively, as compared to that in the crude extract. The disparity (14-fold) in enrichment between the two enzyme activities was thought to be the consequence of either the instability of ACC oxidase activity or the increased ACC synthase activity during the purification processes or both. Based on gel filtration, the molecular mass of the native fusion enzyme was determined to be 360 ± 21 kDa, suggesting that the expressed fusion enzyme is oligomeric rather than monomeric (Fig. 2A). To verify whether the fusion polypeptide was indeed present in the fractions of peak activity, we analyzed the enzyme eluant collected from the peak fractions on SDS-PAGE and performed a Western blot analysis of the protein samples using probes of both the Ni2+-NTA/alkaline phosphatase conjugate and the polyclonal antibodies raised against the tomato ACC oxidase. As expected, there was only one 90-kDa polypeptide cross-reacting with the two probes in the peak fractions (Fig. 2B). Thus, the 90-kDa in-frame fusion enzyme is indeed the subunit of the oligomeric ACSO complex, confirming that the oligomeric fusion enzyme is bifunctional. Since the fusion enzyme, ACSO, has both ACC synthase and ACC oxidase activities, we anticipate that the fusion enzyme should be capable of catalyzing the sequential reactions from AdoMet to ethylene via ACC when appropriate cofactors or cosubstrates are supplemented. We first incubated the crude fusion enzyme with 1 mM AdoMet supplemented with all the known cofactors and cosubstrates necessary for both ACC synthase and ACC oxidase activities under the conditions described under “Experimental Procedures,” and measured the synthesis of ACC as well as ethylene (Fig. 3) in the test tube. It was found that the concentration of ACC peaked at 5 min (2.6 nmol mg−1) and then declined. At the same time, the ethylene level began to increase (Fig. 3). By 30 min of reaction, 71.0 pmol of ethylene had been produced by 1 mg of the fusion enzyme and the concentration of ACC in the reaction mixture was 3.9 μM. The C terminus of tomato ACC synthase was shown to be dispensable in terms of maintaining activity (32Li N. Mattoo A.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6908-6917Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We reasoned that addition of a polypeptide to the C terminus of ACC synthase should not result in an inactive enzyme. The experiment conducted here has proven this to be the case. Addition of a stretch of six consecutive histidines (His-tag) to the N terminus of ACC synthase did not abolish the bifunctionality of the fusion enzyme. Since a deletion of N or C termini of ACC synthase affects the enzyme kinetics (32Li N. Mattoo A.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6908-6917Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 35Li N. Huxtable S. Yang S.F. Kung S.D. FEBS Lett. 1996; 378: 286-290Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar), the possibility that this fusion might change the kinetic properties of both enzymes cannot be ruled out. The actual alteration in enzymatic kinetics of the fusion enzyme awaits further investigation. It is to be noted that specific activity of ACC oxidase is much lower than that of ACC synthase in the fusion enzyme. Such a disparity is consistent with the previous observation that the native ACC oxidase has much lower intrinsic catalytic power than that of ACC synthase (10Dong J.G. Ferná;ndez-Maculet C.J. Yang S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9789-9793Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). For example, the catalytic constants (kcat) for apple ACC synthase and ACC oxidase are 9.2 and 0.013 s−1, respectively (10Dong J.G. Ferná;ndez-Maculet C.J. Yang S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9789-9793Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar, 16White M.F. Vasquez J. Yang S.F. Kirsch J.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 12428-12432Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar, 36Yip W.K. Dong J.G. Yang S.F. Plant Physiol. 1991; 95: 251-257Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). Thus, they differ in catalytic power by a factor of about 700. However, this disparity can be partially compensated by the fact that in plant tissues ACC oxidase is several hundred times more abundant than ACC synthase. In apple fruit, it was estimated that the ACC synthase level is about 0.002% of total cellular protein (36Yip W.K. Dong J.G. Yang S.F. Plant Physiol. 1991; 95: 251-257Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar), whereas the ACC oxidase level is about 0.56% (10Dong J.G. Ferná;ndez-Maculet C.J. Yang S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9789-9793Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). The enzyme assay conditions for ACC synthase and ACC oxidase have been individually established before (7Boller T. Herner R.C. Kende H. Planta. 1979; 145: 293-303Crossref PubMed Scopus (340) Google Scholar, 8Yu Y. Adams A.D. Yang S.F. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1979; 198: 280-286Crossref PubMed Scopus (226) Google Scholar, 9Ververidis P. John P. Phytochemistry. 1991; 30: 725-727Crossref Scopus (221) Google Scholar, 10Dong J.G. Ferná;ndez-Maculet C.J. Yang S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9789-9793Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). To assay for ethylene production of ACSO, the substrate AdoMet, cosubstrate ascorbic acid and cofactors PLP, ferrous iron, and bicarbonate necessary for both ACC synthase and ACC oxidase were added to the reaction mixture. Although the combined reaction mixture has proven to be working (Fig. 3), the optimal reaction conditions for ACSO remains to be worked out. The 360-kDa fusion enzyme complex determined by gel filtration is about 4 times the size of the ACC synthase subunit (90 kDa), suggesting that this fusion enzyme is probably tetrameric. This is unexpected because ACC oxidase was reported to be a monomer (10Dong J.G. Ferná;ndez-Maculet C.J. Yang S.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9789-9793Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar) whereas ACC synthase could be either a monomer or a dimer (32Li N. Mattoo A.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6908-6917Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 37Satoh S. Mori H. Imaseki H. Plant Cell Physiol. 1993; 34: 753-760Crossref Scopus (17) Google Scholar, 38Hohenester E. White M.F. Kirsch J.F. Jansonius J.N. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 243: 947-949Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar). To clarify this point, we are in a process of purifying this fusion enzyme to homogeneity for further biochemical and biophysical characterization. This ethylene-generating fusion enzyme is anticipated to be useful for research in molecular biology, developmental biology, and biotechnology. Ethylene could also be used as a new class of gaseous reporter for monitoring the gene expression in a heterologous model system because the method for measuring gaseous ethylene is simple, fast, sensitive, and nondestructive (5Abeles F.B. Morgan P.W. Saltveit Jr., M.E. Ethylene in Plant Biology. 2nd Ed. Academic Press, Inc., San Diego, CA1992Google Scholar). We thank Drs. J. C. Pech and A. Latche for their generous gift of the polyclonal antibody against a tomato ACC oxidase. We also thank Drs. S. Huxtable, S. J. Yang, and L. Hyatt for their valuable suggestions and B. Yu and R. Dei for their help in preparing figures.

We have mapped the topology of the C-terminal half of the putative potassium channel protein Kch in the inner membrane of Escherichia coli using PhoA fusions. Our results are consistent with the widely assumed six-transmembrane helix model for eukaryotic voltage-gated ion channels and place both ends of the proposed channel-lining P-segment on the periplasmic side of the inner membrane. The rather hydrophobic P-segment is found to translocate only slowly across the inner membrane and seems to be near a threshold for stop-transfer function. We have mapped the topology of the C-terminal half of the putative potassium channel protein Kch in the inner membrane of Escherichia coli using PhoA fusions. Our results are consistent with the widely assumed six-transmembrane helix model for eukaryotic voltage-gated ion channels and place both ends of the proposed channel-lining P-segment on the periplasmic side of the inner membrane. The rather hydrophobic P-segment is found to translocate only slowly across the inner membrane and seems to be near a threshold for stop-transfer function.

The refined three-dimensional structure of native human α2-macroglobulin (α2M) has been determined by cryoelectron microscopy and three-dimensional reconstruction. New features corresponding to “sigmoid arches,”“basal bodies,” and “apical connections” were observed in the molecule. Since similar elements are found in the architecture of transformed α2M, the 2 volumes were aligned in three dimensions. In their common orientations, they show many similarities except near the openings of the central chamber. In the native conformation, these apertures are fully opened, allowing the proteases to access the central chamber of the molecule, while in the transformed structure, they are partially closed. These structures suggest that α2M conformational change involves a strong lateral compression and a vertical stretching of the native particle seen in its four-petaled flower view to produce the H view of the transformed form. A model of structural transformation, in which all the parts of the α2M molecule seem involved in the entrapment of the proteinases is proposed.
